item.title: A Radical Idea to Rebuild a Shattered Libya: Restore the Monarchy
item.description: After years of turmoil and frustration with the United Nations peace process, some suggest that a king can rescue the country.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: King Idris, who was ousted by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in a 1969 coup, in Tripoli in 1953.

item.title: Austria and 9 Balkan States Agree on Steps to Address Refugee Crisis
item.description: The moves, by their foreign and interior ministers, came as Europe prepares for another surge in people fleeing war and poverty in the Middle East and beyond.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Migrants boarded a train on Wednesday after crossing the border from Greece to Macedonia.

item.title: Q. and A.: How Times Journalists Cover the War in Syria
item.description: Anne Barnard, The Times’s Beirut bureau chief, and Hwaida Saad, a bureau reporter and news assistant, answered readers’ questions about Syria on Reddit.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Kobani, Syria, a city devastated by fighting, in October.

item.title: Crackdowns on Protests Rise Across a Europe Increasingly Afraid of Terror
item.description: Spain’s arrests of two puppeteers are the latest in a string of prosecutions fueling a debate on whether freedom of speech is under threat in Europe.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: A rally in Madrid this month protested the arrests of two puppeteers accused of glorifying terrorism and promoting hatred. The puppeteers could face up to seven years in prison.

item.title: South Korea Tells China Not to Intervene in Missile-Defense System Talks
item.description: The decision by Seoul to consider the possible deployment of a U.S. system known as Thaad was based on the need for self-defense, an official said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: United States soldiers passing a protest in Seoul, South Korea, on Tuesday over the possible deployment of an American missile-defense system.

item.title: Malaysian High Court Upholds T-Shirt as a Security Threat
item.description: The T-shirts say “Bersih 4,” the name of a protest in Kuala Lumpur last August. “Bersih” means “clean,” and the protesters were calling for clean government.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.media:description: Protesters gathering in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, in August to demonstrate against the government of Prime Minister Najib Razak. A Malaysian High Court has upheld a government edict declaring yellow shirts that call for a clean government a national security threat.

item.title: SuperReturn International: At Investors’ Conference in Germany, Tepid Support for U.S. Candidates
item.description: David M. Rubenstein of the Carlyle Group asked an audience at a conference to whom, among the presidential hopefuls, they would entrust their money.
item.dc:creator: CHAD BRAY

item.title: Macedonia Postpones Elections Until June Amid Opposition Pressure
item.description: The move came in response to a boycott threat from parties demanding more time to put in place overhauls they said were needed to ensure a fair vote.
item.dc:creator: ALEKSANDAR DIMISHKOVSKI

item.title: Fighting Modern-Day Witch Hunts in India’s Remote Northeast
item.description: Birubala Rabha, an activist, works with state legislators and residents of rural villages in Assam State to end the practice of punishing women accused of witchcraft.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Nepal Plane Wreckage Is Found, Official Says
item.description: There was little chance that any of the 23 people abroad had survived, an official said, and recovery workers were on the site in mountainous terrain.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA
item.media:description: A family member crying as he waited at the airport after a plane, operated by the Nepalese carrier Tara Air, disappeared in Nepal on Wednesday.

item.title: Editorial: How Turkey Misreads the Kurds
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan refuses to acknowledge important differences between the P.K.K. and other groups.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: Turkish policeman and protesters clash during a demonstration against government-imposed curfews.

item.title: Ramón Castro, Brother to Cuban Revolutionaries, Dies at 91
item.description: Mr. Castro, a rancher and the elder brother of Fidel and Raúl, took a smaller role in the country’s Communist revolution and government.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: World Briefing: Nepal: Plane Carrying 23 Is Missing
item.description: A passenger plane carrying 23 people lost contact minutes after takeoff and is missing in mountainous territory, officials here said.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: Ukraine Sings Its Frustration With Russia
item.description: The Ukrainian entry in the 2016 Eurovision song contest is the latest example of popular protest music aimed at Russia.
item.dc:creator: ALISA SOPOVA
item.media:description: Susana Jamaladinova, known as Jamala, performed during the Ukrainian qualification show for the Eurovision song contest on Sunday.

item.title: Bolivia’s President, Evo Morales, Faces Setback in Bid for Fourth Term
item.description: An official tally, with 97 percent of the ballots counted, showed that voters had rejected a bid by President Evo Morales to seek a fourth term.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Sinosphere: Blind Chinese Man’s Guide Dog Is Returned
item.description: Attached to the dog, Qiaoqiao, was a note asking for forgiveness.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: John E. Reinhardt, Ambassador and Head of U.S. Information Agency, Dies at 95
item.description: Dr. Reinhardt was the first black American ambassador to Nigeria, and the first career diplomat and first university educator to lead the information agency.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:description: Vice President Walter Mondale, left, and John E. Reinhardt in April 1978.

item.title: Policy Shifts on Refugees Lead to Clashes Between Migrants and Police
item.description: The Greek riot police forcibly removed protesters from train tracks at a border camp after Macedonia blocked Afghans from seeking political asylum.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: An Afghan man pushing against the border fence during a demonstration on Monday near the Greek village of Idomeni, against Macedonia’s refusal to allow Afghans to pass the border.

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: 7 Charged Over Dam Disaster
item.description: The president of the Samarco mining company and six other people have been charged with aggravated homicide over the deaths of at least 17 people after a dam burst in November.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Court Faults Cleric’s Abduction
item.description: The cleric, Hassan Mustafa Osama Nasr, was seized on a street in Milan by C.I.A. operatives in 2003 and flown to Egypt, where, he said, he was tortured for more than seven months.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
